page.title: 11Chesterton Wood:1
page.content: Chesterton Wood was probably planted because of an agricultural depression and the Corn Laws by an ancestor of Lord Willoughby De Broke in the early 19th century. The 127 acre wood was oak and hazel coppice when first planted but is now largely oak and ash with some pine. Roughly 2/3 of the wood is deciduous trees. Besides the growing of timber as a crop, the wood is also intended for amenity and conservation use. The wood may be visited by arrangement with Mr. R.Tilley whose family are now responsible for it. Traditionally, the general public are allowed into the wood on Good Friday to pick primroses. The timber is used for all sorts of household effects, furniture, tools and sporting goods.
